title: Subtropical Storm Melissa has formed off the coast of New England
text:
Subtropical Storm Melissa has formed off the coast of New England, the National Hurricane Center said.

Even before getting a name, the storm had already been swirling in the same area for a couple of days, bringing driving rain, howling winds, coastal flooding and rough surf primarily to southeastern New England.

More of the same is forecast for the next day or so: "Wind gusts to 50 mph are likely to continue over portions of Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket through much of today," the hurricane center said.

Parts of southeastern New England will likely see an additional 1 to 2 inches of rain, the Weather Channel said.

Some impacts of the storm were forecast to be felt beyond New England: The hurricane center warned that "swells generated by Melissa are affecting much of the U.S. east coast, portions of the Bahamas, Bermuda and Atlantic Canada. These swells will result in life-threatening surf and rip current conditions."

As of 11 a.m. ET, the center of Melissa had maximum sustained winds of 65 mph and was located about 190 miles south of Nantucket Island, Massachusetts. It was moving to the south-southwest at 3 mph.

Here are the 11 am EDT Key #Messages regarding Subtropical Storm Melissa. Latest information: https://t.co/tW4KeFW0gB pic.twitter.com/U84Ezt1Py7 — National Hurricane Center (@NHC_Atlantic) October 11, 2019

"Gradual weakening is expected over the next couple of days, and Melissa is forecast to lose its subtropical characteristics by Saturday night," the hurricane center said.

A subtropical storm is a meteorological term for a hybrid storm that has elements of both tropical and non-tropical storms.

Melissa is the 13th named storm of the 2019 Atlantic hurricane season. A typical season sees about 12 storms.

In the northern Plains: Travel will be 'impossible' in the Dakotas as blizzard could bring up to 3 feet of snow

Meanwhile in California: Saddleridge fire is 'zero' contained as more than 100,000 people evacuate near L

Nor'easter has become Subtropical Storm #Melissa southeast of New England. Coastal flooding and gusty wind remain concerns into tonight: https://t.co/roFVzFK7je pic.twitter.com/dTGibtVuuD — The Weather Channel (@weatherchannel) October 11, 2019

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Subtropical Storm Melissa brings heavy rain to New England, East Coast
description: Subtropical Storm Melissa will bring heavy rain and wind gusts to 50 mph to portions of Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket
